content.description:
Show all your work for each part of the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight.

Two identical rolls of paper have mass <math alttext="M" overflow="scroll"><mi>M</mi></math> and radius <math alttext="R" overflow="scroll"><mi>R</mi></math>. Roll <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> is held at a height <math alttext="h sub 1" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>h</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math> above the ground and dropped from rest. Roll <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> falls to the ground without unrolling. Roll <math alttext="2" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> is held a height <math alttext="h sub 2" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>h</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math> above the ground, where <math alttext="h sub 2 is less than h sub 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>h</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo><</mo><msub><mi>h</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></mstyle></math>. When Roll <math alttext="2" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> is released from rest, the end of Roll <math alttext="2" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> is held in place. Roll <math alttext="2" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> unrolls and rotates while it falls, as shown in Figure <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>. Both rolls are released from rest at time <math alttext="t equals 0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mstyle></math> and reach the ground at the same time <math alttext="t equals t sub 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>t</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></mstyle></math>. The rotational inertia of each roll about the central axis of the roll can be modeled as <math alttext="I equals, one half M R squared" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mi>I</mi><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>2</mn></mfrac><mi>M</mi><msup><mi>R</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></mstyle></math>. \(M\) and \(R\) are considered to be constant as each roll falls.
content.question: (a) Draw and label a force diagram of the forces (not components) exerted on each roll as they fall between <math alttext="t equals 0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="t equals t sub 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>t</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></mstyle></math>. Each force in your force diagram must be represented by a distinct arrow starting on, and pointing away from, the point at which the force is exerted on the roll.

frqParts.text: (a) Draw and label a force diagram of the forces (not components) exerted on each roll as they fall between <math alttext="t equals 0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="t equals t sub 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>t</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></mstyle></math>. Each force in your force diagram must be represented by a distinct arrow starting on, and pointing away from, the point at which the force is exerted on the roll.

(b)

i. Determine an expression for the linear acceleration <math alttext="a sub 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>a</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></mstyle></math> of Roll <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> as it falls in terms of physical constants, as appropriate.

ii. Starting with Newton’s second law in rotational or translational form, derive an expression for the linear acceleration <math alttext="a sub 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>a</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></mstyle></math> of Roll <math alttext="2" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> as it unrolls in terms of physical constants, as appropriate. Begin your derivation by writing a fundamental physics principle or an equation from the reference book.

(c) Figure <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> shows a graph of the linear speed of Roll <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> as a function of time between <math alttext="t equals 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="t equals t sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>t</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></mstyle></math>. The linear speed of Roll <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> just before it hits the ground is <math alttext="v sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>v</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></mstyle></math>. On the same grid, sketch the linear speed of Roll <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> as a function of time between <math alttext="t equals 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="t equals t sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>t</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></mstyle></math>. Clearly label the final speed of Roll <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> as <math alttext="v sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>v</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></mstyle></math>.
(d) Justify how the force diagram created in part (a) is or is not consistent with the graph drawn in part (c).
